history.content:
In many ways, 170 is a direct extension of 61b in terms of data structures, and software at its core relies on effective algorithms for all sorts of computational applications. Even in 126 material you can regularly find use for 170 knowledge, for example, Viterbi algorithm is all kinds of dynamic programming. So while there are no hard class requirements, 170 likely makes great sense to take

-------------------

@6412

In many ways, 170 is a direct extension of 61b in terms of data structures, and software at its core relies on effective algorithms for all sorts of computational applications. Even in 126 material you can regularly find use for 170 knowledge, for example, Viterbi algorithm is all kinds of dynamic programming. So while there are no hard class requirements, 170 likely makes great sense to take

children.subject:
In regards to the student's answer, I would actually argue 170 emphasizes more on 61b algorithms than it is on data structures; for example, with Kruskal MST, we didn't cover union-find.

Here's a list of what 170 essentially covers: https://www.cs.princeton.edu/~wayne/kleinberg-tardos/. My advice would be to take 170 since 61b does not cover dynamic programming, divide-and-conquer, or greedy algorithms sufficiently for SWE interview questions.

history.content: I've recently found interest in data structures/OOP, and would like to potentially consider SWE or DS as potential career options. I'm not a CS major though, and I've only taken CS 61A/B, and don't really have plans to take 61C. I've been reading a lot that CS 170 is a de facto requirement for a CS education at Berkeley. Is CS 170 really that necessary? If I want to potentially work as a SWE, could I get away with not taking CS 170 (and maybe take EECS 126 or 127, since I find that kind of math more interesting), or would I be at a significant disadvantage in terms of knowledge by not taking 170?
history.subject: Can One "Get Away" with Not Taking CS 170?
